commentBody: Very nice! This (mostly) solved smoothly for me, with a couple of misdirects (like LARD as a first guess instead of GHEE). I really liked the clues for the long answers--the care taken in constructing them was evident. Part of me wishes it had been a little harder to complete, but I shouldn't complain--it was fun.

Fun connection between 3D and 15A. Each of the last two years has a cinematic singularity where two tentpoles were released on the same day. Historically that was considered box office poison, but BARBIE and Oppenheimer bolstered each other's box office receipts due to the meme culture that surrounded the Barbenheimer release.

It was such a success that they (somewhat less successfully) tried to replicate it with Glicked last year, the more "popular" half of that pair starring ARIANA Grande...
I done did this puzz
"Black and yellow demarcation" stumped me for a while - police tape in Australia is blue and white!

Guess what would make a good sport nickname? PISTON PETE.

My other desired answer, just because I like the word, sadly did not fit: SHILLELAGH.
Britney was and is, and will forever be the only princess of pop.  All others rise on her.

Nice puzzle that had tons of sports and music answers that were right in my wheelhouse.  PISTOLPETE Maravich crossing LEN Dawson brought back sports memories from my youth.  Maravich, with his floppy hair and floppy socks was one of the NBA‚Äôs preeminent long range shooters.  Alas for Pete he played 9 of his 10 seasons before the NBA adopted the three point line.  Pete routinely shot from three point range when such shots were worth no more than a layup.  Then by the time the league adopted the three pointer, injuries had severely limited his effectiveness and he retired.  Eight years later he died at the age of 40.  His candle burned brightly before it burned out.
Tough but fair, really well done, no dud clues and some excellent ones.
I really enjoyed this one. It was quite challenging and a very satisfying solve.

That was fun!  Had difficulty finding a toehold at first, but Barbie and sibling rivalry saved the day. Never had anything Barbie in the 60‚Äôs because we were too poor, but we had plenty of sibling rivalry. My mother‚Äôs favorite catchphrase when we were engaging in ‚Äúsibling rivalry‚Äù was ‚Äúlet it go‚Äù so I loved seeing both answers in the same puzzle. Happy Friday!

Very nice. I don't do sportsball, and  I'd never heard of Maravich but was able to guess from a few crosses. I did remember LEN Dawson... from another puzzle, probably! Anyway, a fun start to the summer (which started at 10:42 EDT).
Simply too easy for a Saturday.
Took me forever, mostly due to the abundance of proper names of mid-tier notoriety.
Took 60% of my average time to complete.  Some answers in the SE held me up briefly.  It helped that the spanners came to me pretty quickly.

For some reason, I was able to get the long spanners with either no crosses, or fewer than I usually need.

That was crucial, because this time it was the shorter ones that bedeviled me:  ORAN, TRI, PLEAS, PIERS.

I will say that I got 44D fairly quickly.  

Does anyone else miss Dr. Ruth Westheimer?  I loved hearing that sweet little old lady talking about the most scandalous topics just like she was giving a pie recipe.
Lots of very average to poor clues. Few good clues, maybe 13d
Not to be a party pooper, but I was shocked that there were SEVEN proper nouns that I had never heard of and had to look up :( must be a generation gap?

Pretty simple, except my phone must have been out of signal and it didn't register properly when complete.  This has happened to me twice before when traveling but I didn't bother to correct the "streak".  This time I will.  I can't believe they haven't fixed this problem after several years.  How hard is it to do a handshake when the page reloads??  How can a streak be marked broken when it's still the same day (barely into Saturday at this writing) and the puzzle is complete?  Sigh.

The people who found this one easy were lucky and got one in their sweet spot.  For the rest of us, all those proper names were a quagmire.  But once I got the inevitable look-ups out of the way, everything was very quick, and the fills lit up like smiling innocent friends.

Took some time out in the middle of the solve to watch Episode 6 of "Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy." When things get iffy we often haul out the DVDs and rely on some timeless entertainment to divert us‚Äîthis time from the frightful situation we're all in these days. Guinness and that terrific cast have offered help through other difficult times in the past.

Christina and Doug, your puzzle was a good one, however much any of us complain about people we didn't know, sometimes presented in unexpected ways.  Good for you.  You did a fine job, and thank you.

I needed at least a dozen lookups to make any real progress, but even then I had almost nothing in the bottom 40% of the grid. I needed to turn on autocheck to finish.

This was probably an enjoyable challenge for crossword puzzle veterans. Me it defeated.

What is an ORG chart and why was there no indication of an abbreviation being involved? Is it an organizational chart? I have no other theory, but then, why no "abbr."?

Santa took twine and ribbon,

Some interesting algebra associated with today's grid. 

Just (15 + 1) x (15 - 1) = (15^2 - 1) = 224 boxes in today's grid, and only 224 - 2(15 - 1) = 196 = (15 - 1)^2 of them needed to be filled. (Let x = 15 if you like doing algebra.)

Happy to say I filled them correctly and without assistance, at an average rate of about 7.2 sec/box. (Fast for me on a Saturday.)

The spanners SIBLINGRIVALRY, STOPPEDONADIME, BARBIEDREAMHOUSE and RAILROADSTATIONS were all solid, as were the near spanners POLICETAPE, HEARTSMART, PISTOLPETE and PRIVATEJET. 

Almost blew this one with IHATETO rather than IHAVETO, but fortunately I reviewed my grid and noticed that STELTE looked a bit odd.

A few too many names for my liking, but I knew most of them. LOESSER with LAN and ORG was troublesome, but I understood LAN and assumed an ORG chart is an organizational chart. (Which is now not an abbreviation because ... people are too rushed to write "organizational"?)

Solid, professional puzzle, but perhaps a bit to gentle for a Saturday offering.

This is a philosophical rhetorical question...so it may be a little longwinded.

In recent history, I've noticed complaints about too much "trivia" in some puzzles.

Im not really sure what that means.

Aren't crossword puzzles all trivia?  Where's the line between things one is assumed to know vs things one may not know?  And if one doesn't know it, does that make it trivia?

As an example...there are dozens of European rivers which have shown up in crossword puzzles over the years...Some of the easiest are the Thames, the Seine, and the Danube....But there are dozens after than which a person will be less likely to know off the top of their head.

Or is the real issue with "trivia" really about pop culture and age?  If youre of a certain age you'll more likely know an answer...and if youre not of that age you might not.

If the question was "Mondale's running mate?"...You might get an answer immediately...or a few seconds of forget with an easy fill with a few letters...or you might get Who is Mondale? 

It just seems to me that every inch of a crossword puzzle is trivia...and the question then becomes...How broad is your knowledge?  AND do you want to expand that knowledge for the next puzzle?

Dogged determination got me to the finish line, but there was a lot to like in this puzzle.  References to many of my interests including sports, TRI, PISTOLPETE and LEN, music, LETITGO, ARIANA, LOESSER, and food, GHEE, ROTI.

And that brings up "ƒê·ªìng".  The accents are everything.
The crossbar on the "D" indicates a hard "D", without it, its a soft
"D", pronounced like a "Z". It can carry easily 6 or more meanings depending
on how you prounounce it.

Dong (no mark): Mid-level, flat tone.
ƒê·ªìng (grave accent): Low, falling tone. It means the Vietnamese currency.
ƒê·ªèng (hook above): Dipping and rising tone. It can be found in words like "ƒë·ªèng ƒë·∫£nh" (petulant, fussy).
ƒê√µng (tilde): Rising and glottalized tone. It can be found in words like "ƒë√µng ƒë√† ƒë√µng ƒë·∫£nh", which suggests a flirtatious or coquettish manner.
ƒê√≥ng (acute accent): High, rising tone, meaning "to close" or "to seal".
ƒê·ªçng (underdot): Low, heavy tone, meaning "to accumulate" or "to be left over".

Very difficult for non-native speakers to get right, so you wonder why they
are laughing when you weren't trying to make a joke.

So many delightful stories about Barbie memories below, especially from those of us who did not have Dreamhouses. Here's mine.

When all the neighborhood kids of the female persuasion were playing with Barbies, my mother finally broke down because she was concerned that not having them was affecting our socialization. So she decided to get us some, but she did it her way. 

First, she did not believe in gendered toys. (This was in 1964.) If one of us got a doll, we all would. Finally, she compromised and got a Barbie for my little sister, a Midge for me, a Ken for one brother and an Allen for my other brother. Then she told us that this was _all_ she was buying, what they came in. Any accessories, we'd have to make for ourselves.

This lasted until my father's mother jumped in. An accomplished seamstress who made all our clothes (including our winter coats and most of our underwear), she fashioned all kinds of jewel-like clothes from scraps from her regular sewing, including tiny bras and bathing suits. 

I really wanted a Dreamhouse, though. Until one of my friends got one. I took one look at it and thought, "Meh." No where near elegant enough for those wonderful clothes. 

As much as my mother tried not to treat us differently according to gender, her efforts with the dolls failed. My sister and I ended up with our brothers' dolls. We still have them.

I've worked with Army Officers who could read through statistical data and retain it word for word. When briefing the Colonel or General, they possessed the gift to speak authoritatively on any task assigned to their unit. I've always envied that ability.

In my second career, I worked with engineers, attorneys, logisticians, etc., who possessed the same gift. They could retain such knowledge. Most of us do not. 

When I studied for the next professional certification in the tech industry, I had to learn, love and dissect the topics, fail 2-3 exams, then finally passed with 85-ish scores. Others would seemingly breeze over the material, take a few practice exams, and score high in the 90s. Not me.

Jeopardy! champions fall into that category, as to cruciverbalists. I envy them all. Me? I just want the voices to stop (that part was sarcastic). I wouldn't want what goes on in their head in mine.

@Tex 
I find both to be true. Some puzzles that others find hard are clearly in my sweet spot, while others I get through with craft and wile and teeth gnashing.

@Jerry
I would love to have had some kind of mathematical ability, but there has always been a wall between me and numbers.  When I had to take an algebra course in college, the kind T.A.who was teaching it offered to tutor me if I would come to his office hours several times a week. I knew it was hopeless, but even so, I staggered through the class and passed it.

When I was 20 years old I had a job where I was assigned to take notes at board of directors' meetings. They somehow had the idea that I knew shorthand.  I didn't, but all I had to do during the meetings was record any numbers.  I went back to my office, typed up everything that had happened from the beginning of the meeting, including everything that had been said, verbatim.  After a few meetings, the chair read my notes and said, "I watched you during the meeting and I don't think you take shorthand, but it's all here.  I don't know how you do it, but let's just keep that to ourselves."  At that time and for years afterward I was a sort of human recording machine.    

I have the feeling that you have a store of knowledge that I could never have mastered. The human brain is staggeringly complex, and the capacity for learning and retaining is all over the place.  

I don't know when I lost that talent for extreme remembering, somewhere in my 50s maybe, but now, at the age of 90, I feel lucky that I know what day it is.
